title: Why did the American Natives speak Spanish to the first English men? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Most Native Americans at the time of the British invasion had lived in the Viceroyalty of NEW SPAIN for about a century. “It included what is now Mexico plus the current U.S. states of California, Nevada, Colorado, Utah, New Mexico, Arizona, Texas, Oregon, Washington, Florida and parts of Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Kansas, Oklahoma, Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana; the southwestern part of British Columbia of present-day Canada; the Captaincy General of Guatemala (which included the current countries of Guatemala, Belize, Costa Rica, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, and the Mexican state of Chiapas); the Captaincy General of Cuba (current Cuba, Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, and Trinidad and Tobago); and the Captaincy General of the Philippines (including the Philippines, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, the Caroline Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia, Palau, the Marshall Islands, and the short lived Spanish Formosa in modern-day northern Taiwan, as well as, for a century, the island of Tidore and the briefly occupied Sultanate of Ternate, both in modern-day Indonesia).”

Because their natural language was Spanish. They all spoke it. Even today most people in South America speak it. And Central America. So it must have been pretty common for all of the Indians to speak it. So when the English first encountered people like the Ojibway, or the Huron, or the Iroquois, those people must have been speaking Spanish and the English couldn’t understand them. That probably started some of the troubles. If they would have been Christian, they would have spoken English, because obviously that’s what the Bible is written in and that’s what Jesus spoke. So it’s really a shame if you think about it.

They did not. The first “English” explorer was John and Sebastian Cabot, Italians working for Henry the VII - a Tudor king. No one knows where he landed, and the records of native speech he kept were not precise, but it is felt he heard a language in the Huron group. Spanish was encountered inland in the 17th century among some tribes, but the devastation of disease rocked the northern continent long before the English got serious about visiting under Elizabeth.

The American Indians probably met the Spanish before they did the first English, and assumed that all those pale foreigners riding big dogs with shiny stuff on their chests and torsos were the same. To be fair, many Spaniards and Englishmen did wear the same styles of armor and helmets, when not in full harness.

Because they had previous contact with Spanish white men, and assumed these were from the same country. This, being true of Florida, I assume, because, the Virginian and Massachusetts Natives wouldn't have had that contact.
Actually one of the first American native to speak to the New England colonists spoke in pretty good English, which he had picked up in England after being taken there by some European fishermen.
Indians ?? They were trying to hide the fact that they had already settled this land and hoped the white man would go away if they thought the Spanish were already here.
Because they were engaging in Spanish speaking Mexico, before it had been taken over by the US.
